to me in a number of dimensions and so we in practice explore not so much the
local stuff but you know how we can provide transparency and control and a
variety of other approaches that are lighter weight and might aggregate over more and more people
it's also an interesting question about personalization and serendipity you hear
this a lot it doesn't mean the end of serendipity and we have some results that suggest
that it can actually increase serendipity so we did an experiment in
which we looked at relevance versus interestingness so for any search result we asked people to say is this relevant
to your query or is it interesting to your query do now personalization not surprisingly
finds more relevant results that's what you'd hope it also found more interesting results and
even when the results weren't the interesting results were not relevant and I think the reason for this is when
people talk about serendipity they don't want random things they want things that are related and grounded in
something about what they already learn and do and push out in interesting directions and so that's why
personalization helped I think in spite of the fact that the results might have been that might not have been relevant they
were grounded in something about the individual provided ways to expand in ways that were not completely random and
so like the princes of Serendip in the old fable you need to be ready for serendipity and I think personalization
actually provides kind of guardrails about not going too far off things that are relevant and interesting

about who's asking when it is where they are what other things they've interacted with what tasks they might be doing
